<dd><code>nanos</code> - the nanos to add, may be negative</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>an <code>OffsetDateTime</code> based on this date-time with the nanoseconds added, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the unit cannot be added to this type</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="minus(java.time.temporal.TemporalAmount)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>minus</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;minus&#8203;(<a href="temporal/TemporalAmount.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">TemporalAmount</a>&nbsp;amountToSubtract)</pre>
<div class="block">Returns a copy of this date-time with the specified amount subtracted.
 <p>
 This returns an <code>OffsetDateTime</code>, based on this one, with the specified amount subtracted.
 The amount is typically <a href="Period.html" title="class in java.time"><code>Period</code></a> or <a href="Duration.html" title="class in java.time"><code>Duration</code></a> but may be
 any other type implementing the <a href="temporal/TemporalAmount.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal"><code>TemporalAmount</code></a> interface.
 </p><p>
 The calculation is delegated to the amount object by calling
 <a href="temporal/TemporalAmount.html#subtractFrom(java.time.temporal.Temporal)"><code>TemporalAmount.subtractFrom(Temporal)</code></a>. The amount implementation is free
 to implement the subtraction in any way it wishes, however it typically
 calls back to <a href="#minus(long,java.time.temporal.TemporalUnit)"><code>minus(long, TemporalUnit)</code></a>. Consult the documentation
 of the amount implementation to determine if it can be successfully subtracted.
 </p><p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Specified by:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="temporal/Temporal.html#minus(java.time.temporal.TemporalAmount)">minus</a></code>&nbsp;in interface&nbsp;<code><a href="temporal/Temporal.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">Temporal</a></code></dd>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>amountToSubtract</code> - the amount to subtract, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>an <code>OffsetDateTime</code> based on this date-time with the subtraction made, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the subtraction cannot be made</dd>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/ArithmeticException.html" title="class in java.lang">ArithmeticException</a></code> - if numeric overflow occurs</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="minus(long,java.time.temporal.TemporalUnit)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>minus</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;minus&#8203;(long&nbsp;amountToSubtract,
                            <a href="temporal/TemporalUnit.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">TemporalUnit</a>&nbsp;unit)</pre>
<div class="block">Returns a copy of this date-time with the specified amount subtracted.
 <p>
 This returns an <code>OffsetDateTime</code>, based on this one, with the amount
 in terms of the unit subtracted. If it is not possible to subtract the amount,
 because the unit is not supported or for some other reason, an exception is thrown.
 </p><p>
 This method is equivalent to <a href="#plus(long,java.time.temporal.TemporalUnit)"><code>plus(long, TemporalUnit)</code></a> with the amount negated.
 See that method for a full description of how addition, and thus subtraction, works.
 </p><p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Specified by:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="temporal/Temporal.html#minus(long,java.time.temporal.TemporalUnit)">minus</a></code>&nbsp;in interface&nbsp;<code><a href="temporal/Temporal.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">Temporal</a></code></dd>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>amountToSubtract</code> - the amount of the unit to subtract from the result, may be negative</dd>
<dd><code>unit</code> - the unit of the amount to subtract, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>an <code>OffsetDateTime</code> based on this date-time with the specified amount subtracted, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the subtraction cannot be made</dd>
<dd><code><a href="temporal/UnsupportedTemporalTypeException.html" title="class in java.time.temporal">UnsupportedTemporalTypeException</a></code> - if the unit is not supported</dd>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/ArithmeticException.html" title="class in java.lang">ArithmeticException</a></code> - if numeric overflow occurs</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="minusYears(long)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>minusYears</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;minusYears&#8203;(long&nbsp;years)</pre>
<div class="block">Returns a copy of this <code>OffsetDateTime</code> with the specified number of years subtracted.
 <p>
 This method subtracts the specified amount from the years field in three steps:
 <ol>
 <li>Subtract the input years from the year field</li>
 <li>Check if the resulting date would be invalid</li>
 <li>Adjust the day-of-month to the last valid day if necessary</li>
 </ol>
 </p><p>
 For example, 2008-02-29 (leap year) minus one year would result in the
 invalid date 2007-02-29 (standard year). Instead of returning an invalid
 result, the last valid day of the month, 2007-02-28, is selected instead.
 </p><p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>years</code> - the years to subtract, may be negative</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>an <code>OffsetDateTime</code> based on this date-time with the years subtracted, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the result exceeds the supported date range</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="minusMonths(long)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>minusMonths</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;minusMonths&#8203;(long&nbsp;months)</pre>
<div class="block">Returns a copy of this <code>OffsetDateTime</code> with the specified number of months subtracted.
 <p>
 This method subtracts the specified amount from the months field in three steps:
 <ol>
 <li>Subtract the input months from the month-of-year field</li>
 <li>Check if the resulting date would be invalid</li>
 <li>Adjust the day-of-month to the last valid day if necessary</li>
 </ol>
 </p><p>
 For example, 2007-03-31 minus one month would result in the invalid date
 2007-02-31. Instead of returning an invalid result, the last valid day
 of the month, 2007-02-28, is selected instead.
 </p><p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>months</code> - the months to subtract, may be negative</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>an <code>OffsetDateTime</code> based on this date-time with the months subtracted, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the result exceeds the supported date range</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="minusWeeks(long)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>minusWeeks</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;minusWeeks&#8203;(long&nbsp;weeks)</pre>
<div class="block">Returns a copy of this <code>OffsetDateTime</code> with the specified number of weeks subtracted.
 <p>
 This method subtracts the specified amount in weeks from the days field decrementing
 the month and year fields as necessary to ensure the result remains valid.
 The result is only invalid if the maximum/minimum year is exceeded.
 </p><p>
 For example, 2009-01-07 minus one week would result in 2008-12-31.
 </p><p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>weeks</code> - the weeks to subtract, may be negative</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>an <code>OffsetDateTime</code> based on this date-time with the weeks subtracted, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the result exceeds the supported date range</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="minusDays(long)">

<ul class="blockList">

<h4>minusDays</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;minusDays&#8203;(long&nbsp;days)</pre>
<div class="block">Returns a copy of this <code>OffsetDateTime</code> with the specified number of days subtracted.
 <p>
 This method subtracts the specified amount from the days field decrementing the
 month and year fields as necessary to ensure the result remains valid.
 The result is only invalid if the maximum/minimum year is exceeded.
 </p><p>
 For example, 2009-01-01 minus one day would result in 2008-12-31.
 </p><p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>

<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>

<a id="minusSeconds(long)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>minusSeconds</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;minusSeconds&#8203;(long&nbsp;seconds)</pre>
<div class="block">Returns a copy of this <code>OffsetDateTime</code> with the specified number of seconds subtracted.
 <p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>seconds</code> - the seconds to subtract, may be negative</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>

<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the result exceeds the supported date range</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="minusNanos(long)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>minusNanos</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;minusNanos&#8203;(long&nbsp;nanos)</pre>
<div class="block">Returns a copy of this <code>OffsetDateTime</code> with the specified number of nanoseconds subtracted.
 <p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>nanos</code> - the nanos to subtract, may be negative</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>

<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the result exceeds the supported date range</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="query(java.time.temporal.TemporalQuery)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>query</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;&lt;R&gt;&nbsp;R&nbsp;query&#8203;(<a href="temporal/TemporalQuery.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">TemporalQuery</a>&lt;R&gt;&nbsp;query)</pre>
<div class="block">Queries this date-time using the specified query.
 <p>
 This queries this date-time using the specified query strategy object.
 The <code>TemporalQuery</code> object defines the logic to be used to
 obtain the result. Read the documentation of the query to understand
 what the result of this method will be.
 </p><p>
 The result of this method is obtained by invoking the
 <a href="temporal/TemporalQuery.html#queryFrom(java.time.temporal.TemporalAccessor)"><code>TemporalQuery.queryFrom(TemporalAccessor)</code></a> method on the
 specified query passing <code>this</code> as the argument.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Specified by:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="temporal/TemporalAccessor.html#query(java.time.temporal.TemporalQuery)">query</a></code>&nbsp;in interface&nbsp;<code><a href="temporal/TemporalAccessor.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">TemporalAccessor</a></code></dd>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Type Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>R</code> - the type of the result</dd>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>query</code> - the query to invoke, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>the query result, null may be returned (defined by the query)</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if unable to query (defined by the query)</dd>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/ArithmeticException.html" title="class in java.lang">ArithmeticException</a></code> - if numeric overflow occurs (defined by the query)</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="adjustInto(java.time.temporal.Temporal)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>adjustInto</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="temporal/Temporal.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">Temporal</a>&nbsp;adjustInto&#8203;(<a href="temporal/Temporal.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">Temporal</a>&nbsp;temporal)</pre>
<div class="block">Adjusts the specified temporal object to have the same offset, date
 and time as this object.
 <p>
 This returns a temporal object of the same observable type as the input
 with the offset, date and time changed to be the same as this.
 </p><p>
 The adjustment is equivalent to using <a href="temporal/Temporal.html#with(java.time.temporal.TemporalField,long)"><code>Temporal.with(TemporalField, long)</code></a>
 three times, passing <a href="temporal/ChronoField.html#EPOCH_DAY"><code>ChronoField.EPOCH_DAY</code></a>,
 <a href="temporal/ChronoField.html#NANO_OF_DAY"><code>ChronoField.NANO_OF_DAY</code></a> and <a href="temporal/ChronoField.html#OFFSET_SECONDS"><code>ChronoField.OFFSET_SECONDS</code></a> as the fields.
 </p><p>
 In most cases, it is clearer to reverse the calling pattern by using
 <a href="temporal/Temporal.html#with(java.time.temporal.TemporalAdjuster)"><code>Temporal.with(TemporalAdjuster)</code></a>:
 <pre>
   // these two lines are equivalent, but the second approach is recommended
   temporal = thisOffsetDateTime.adjustInto(temporal);
   temporal = temporal.with(thisOffsetDateTime);
 </pre>
 </p><p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Specified by:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="temporal/TemporalAdjuster.html#adjustInto(java.time.temporal.Temporal)">adjustInto</a></code>&nbsp;in interface&nbsp;<code><a href="temporal/TemporalAdjuster.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">TemporalAdjuster</a></code></dd>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>temporal</code> - the target object to be adjusted, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>the adjusted object, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if unable to make the adjustment</dd>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/ArithmeticException.html" title="class in java.lang">ArithmeticException</a></code> - if numeric overflow occurs</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="until(java.time.temporal.Temporal,java.time.temporal.TemporalUnit)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>until</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;long&nbsp;until&#8203;(<a href="temporal/Temporal.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">Temporal</a>&nbsp;endExclusive,
                  <a href="temporal/TemporalUnit.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">TemporalUnit</a>&nbsp;unit)</pre>
<div class="block">Calculates the amount of time until another date-time in terms of the specified unit.
 <p>
 This calculates the amount of time between two <code>OffsetDateTime</code>
 objects in terms of a single <code>TemporalUnit</code>.
 The start and end points are <code>this</code> and the specified date-time.
 The result will be negative if the end is before the start.
 For example, the amount in days between two date-times can be calculated
 using <code>startDateTime.until(endDateTime, DAYS)</code>.
 </p><p>
 The <code>Temporal</code> passed to this method is converted to a
 <code>OffsetDateTime</code> using <a href="#from(java.time.temporal.TemporalAccessor)"><code>from(TemporalAccessor)</code></a>.
 If the offset differs between the two date-times, the specified
 end date-time is normalized to have the same offset as this date-time.
 </p><p>
 The calculation returns a whole number, representing the number of
 complete units between the two date-times.
 For example, the amount in months between 2012-06-15T00:00Z and 2012-08-14T23:59Z
 will only be one month as it is one minute short of two months.
 </p><p>
 There are two equivalent ways of using this method.
 The first is to invoke this method.
 The second is to use <a href="temporal/TemporalUnit.html#between(java.time.temporal.Temporal,java.time.temporal.Temporal)"><code>TemporalUnit.between(Temporal, Temporal)</code></a>:
 <pre>
   // these two lines are equivalent
   amount = start.until(end, MONTHS);
   amount = MONTHS.between(start, end);
 </pre>
 The choice should be made based on which makes the code more readable.
 </p><p>
 The calculation is implemented in this method for <a href="temporal/ChronoUnit.html" title="enum in java.time.temporal"><code>ChronoUnit</code></a>.
 The units <code>NANOS</code>, <code>MICROS</code>, <code>MILLIS</code>, <code>SECONDS</code>,
 <code>MINUTES</code>, <code>HOURS</code> and <code>HALF_DAYS</code>, <code>DAYS</code>,
 <code>WEEKS</code>, <code>MONTHS</code>, <code>YEARS</code>, <code>DECADES</code>,
 <code>CENTURIES</code>, <code>MILLENNIA</code> and <code>ERAS</code> are supported.
 Other <code>ChronoUnit</code> values will throw an exception.
 </p><p>
 If the unit is not a <code>ChronoUnit</code>, then the result of this method
 is obtained by invoking <code>TemporalUnit.between(Temporal, Temporal)</code>
 passing <code>this</code> as the first argument and the converted input temporal
 as the second argument.
 </p><p>
 This instance is immutable and unaffected by this method call.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Specified by:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="temporal/Temporal.html#until(java.time.temporal.Temporal,java.time.temporal.TemporalUnit)">until</a></code>&nbsp;in interface&nbsp;<code><a href="temporal/Temporal.html" title="interface in java.time.temporal">Temporal</a></code></dd>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>endExclusive</code> - the end date, exclusive, which is converted to an <code>OffsetDateTime</code>, not null</dd>
<dd><code>unit</code> - the unit to measure the amount in, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>the amount of time between this date-time and the end date-time</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if the amount cannot be calculated, or the end
  temporal cannot be converted to an <code>OffsetDateTime</code></dd>
<dd><code><a href="temporal/UnsupportedTemporalTypeException.html" title="class in java.time.temporal">UnsupportedTemporalTypeException</a></code> - if the unit is not supported</dd>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/ArithmeticException.html" title="class in java.lang">ArithmeticException</a></code> - if numeric overflow occurs</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="format(java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>format</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="../lang/String.html" title="class in java.lang">String</a>&nbsp;format&#8203;(<a href="format/DateTimeFormatter.html" title="class in java.time.format">DateTimeFormatter</a>&nbsp;formatter)</pre>
<div class="block">Formats this date-time using the specified formatter.
 <p>
 This date-time will be passed to the formatter to produce a string.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>formatter</code> - the formatter to use, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>the formatted date-time string, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="throwsLabel">Throws:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="DateTimeException.html" title="class in java.time">DateTimeException</a></code> - if an error occurs during printing</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="atZoneSameInstant(java.time.ZoneId)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>atZoneSameInstant</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="ZonedDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">ZonedDateTime</a>&nbsp;atZoneSameInstant&#8203;(<a href="ZoneId.html" title="class in java.time">ZoneId</a>&nbsp;zone)</pre>
<div class="block">Combines this date-time with a time-zone to create a <code>ZonedDateTime</code>
 ensuring that the result has the same instant.
 <p>
 This returns a <code>ZonedDateTime</code> formed from this date-time and the specified time-zone.
 This conversion will ignore the visible local date-time and use the underlying instant instead.
 This avoids any problems with local time-line gaps or overlaps.
 The result might have different values for fields such as hour, minute an even day.
 </p><p>
 To attempt to retain the values of the fields, use <a href="#atZoneSimilarLocal(java.time.ZoneId)"><code>atZoneSimilarLocal(ZoneId)</code></a>.
 To use the offset as the zone ID, use <a href="#toZonedDateTime()"><code>toZonedDateTime()</code></a>.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>zone</code> - the time-zone to use, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>the zoned date-time formed from this date-time, not null</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="atZoneSimilarLocal(java.time.ZoneId)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>atZoneSimilarLocal</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="ZonedDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">ZonedDateTime</a>&nbsp;atZoneSimilarLocal&#8203;(<a href="ZoneId.html" title="class in java.time">ZoneId</a>&nbsp;zone)</pre>
<div class="block">Combines this date-time with a time-zone to create a <code>ZonedDateTime</code>
 trying to keep the same local date and time.
 <p>
 This returns a <code>ZonedDateTime</code> formed from this date-time and the specified time-zone.
 Where possible, the result will have the same local date-time as this object.
 </p><p>
 Time-zone rules, such as daylight savings, mean that not every time on the
 local time-line exists. If the local date-time is in a gap or overlap according to
 the rules then a resolver is used to determine the resultant local time and offset.
 This method uses <a href="ZonedDateTime.html#ofLocal(java.time.LocalDateTime,java.time.ZoneId,java.time.ZoneOffset)"><code>ZonedDateTime.ofLocal(LocalDateTime, ZoneId, ZoneOffset)</code></a>
 to retain the offset from this instance if possible.
 </p><p>
 Finer control over gaps and overlaps is available in two ways.
 If you simply want to use the later offset at overlaps then call
 <a href="ZonedDateTime.html#withLaterOffsetAtOverlap()"><code>ZonedDateTime.withLaterOffsetAtOverlap()</code></a> immediately after this method.
 </p><p>
 To create a zoned date-time at the same instant irrespective of the local time-line,
 use <a href="#atZoneSameInstant(java.time.ZoneId)"><code>atZoneSameInstant(ZoneId)</code></a>.
 To use the offset as the zone ID, use <a href="#toZonedDateTime()"><code>toZonedDateTime()</code></a>.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>zone</code> - the time-zone to use, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>the zoned date-time formed from this date and the earliest valid time for the zone, not null</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="toOffsetTime()">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>toOffsetTime</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="OffsetTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetTime</a>&nbsp;toOffsetTime()</pre>
<div class="block">Converts this date-time to an <code>OffsetTime</code>.
 <p>
 This returns an offset time with the same local time and offset.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>an OffsetTime representing the time and offset, not null</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="toZonedDateTime()">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>toZonedDateTime</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="ZonedDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">ZonedDateTime</a>&nbsp;toZonedDateTime()</pre>
<div class="block">Converts this date-time to a <code>ZonedDateTime</code> using the offset as the zone ID.
 <p>
 This creates the simplest possible <code>ZonedDateTime</code> using the offset
 as the zone ID.
 </p><p>
 To control the time-zone used, see <a href="#atZoneSameInstant(java.time.ZoneId)"><code>atZoneSameInstant(ZoneId)</code></a> and
 <a href="#atZoneSimilarLocal(java.time.ZoneId)"><code>atZoneSimilarLocal(ZoneId)</code></a>.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>a zoned date-time representing the same local date-time and offset, not null</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="toInstant()">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>toInstant</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="Instant.html" title="class in java.time">Instant</a>&nbsp;toInstant()</pre>
<div class="block">Converts this date-time to an <code>Instant</code>.
 <p>
 This returns an <code>Instant</code> representing the same point on the
 time-line as this date-time.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>an <code>Instant</code> representing the same instant, not null</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="toEpochSecond()">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>toEpochSecond</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;long&nbsp;toEpochSecond()</pre>
<div class="block">Converts this date-time to the number of seconds from the epoch of 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z.
 <p>
 This allows this date-time to be converted to a value of the
 <a href="temporal/ChronoField.html#INSTANT_SECONDS"><code>epoch-seconds</code></a> field. This is primarily
 intended for low-level conversions rather than general application usage.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>the number of seconds from the epoch of 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="compareTo(java.time.OffsetDateTime)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>compareTo</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;int&nbsp;compareTo&#8203;(<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;other)</pre>
<div class="block">Compares this date-time to another date-time.
 <p>
 The comparison is based on the instant then on the local date-time.
 It is "consistent with equals", as defined by <a href="../lang/Comparable.html" title="interface in java.lang"><code>Comparable</code></a>.
 </p><p>
 For example, the following is the comparator order:
 <ol>
 <li><code>2008-12-03T10:30+01:00</code></li>
 <li><code>2008-12-03T11:00+01:00</code></li>
 <li><code>2008-12-03T12:00+02:00</code></li>
 <li><code>2008-12-03T11:30+01:00</code></li>
 <li><code>2008-12-03T12:00+01:00</code></li>
 <li><code>2008-12-03T12:30+01:00</code></li>
 </ol>
 Values #2 and #3 represent the same instant on the time-line.
 When two values represent the same instant, the local date-time is compared
 to distinguish them. This step is needed to make the ordering
 consistent with <code>equals()</code>.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Specified by:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/Comparable.html#compareTo(T)">compareTo</a></code>&nbsp;in interface&nbsp;<code><a href="../lang/Comparable.html" title="interface in java.lang">Comparable</a>&lt;<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&gt;</code></dd>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>other</code> - the other date-time to compare to, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>the comparator value, negative if less, positive if greater</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="isAfter(java.time.OffsetDateTime)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>isAfter</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;boolean&nbsp;isAfter&#8203;(<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;other)</pre>
<div class="block">Checks if the instant of this date-time is after that of the specified date-time.
 <p>
 This method differs from the comparison in <a href="#compareTo(java.time.OffsetDateTime)"><code>compareTo(java.time.OffsetDateTime)</code></a> and <a href="#equals(java.lang.Object)"><code>equals(java.lang.Object)</code></a> in that it
 only compares the instant of the date-time. This is equivalent to using
 <code>dateTime1.toInstant().isAfter(dateTime2.toInstant());</code>.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>other</code> - the other date-time to compare to, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>true if this is after the instant of the specified date-time</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="isBefore(java.time.OffsetDateTime)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>isBefore</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;boolean&nbsp;isBefore&#8203;(<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;other)</pre>
<div class="block">Checks if the instant of this date-time is before that of the specified date-time.
 <p>
 This method differs from the comparison in <a href="#compareTo(java.time.OffsetDateTime)"><code>compareTo(java.time.OffsetDateTime)</code></a> in that it
 only compares the instant of the date-time. This is equivalent to using
 <code>dateTime1.toInstant().isBefore(dateTime2.toInstant());</code>.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>other</code> - the other date-time to compare to, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>true if this is before the instant of the specified date-time</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="isEqual(java.time.OffsetDateTime)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>isEqual</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;boolean&nbsp;isEqual&#8203;(<a href="OffsetDateTime.html" title="class in java.time">OffsetDateTime</a>&nbsp;other)</pre>
<div class="block">Checks if the instant of this date-time is equal to that of the specified date-time.
 <p>
 This method differs from the comparison in <a href="#compareTo(java.time.OffsetDateTime)"><code>compareTo(java.time.OffsetDateTime)</code></a> and <a href="#equals(java.lang.Object)"><code>equals(java.lang.Object)</code></a>
 in that it only compares the instant of the date-time. This is equivalent to using
 <code>dateTime1.toInstant().equals(dateTime2.toInstant());</code>.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>other</code> - the other date-time to compare to, not null</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>true if the instant equals the instant of the specified date-time</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="equals(java.lang.Object)">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>equals</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;boolean&nbsp;equals&#8203;(<a href="../lang/Object.html" title="class in java.lang">Object</a>&nbsp;obj)</pre>
<div class="block">Checks if this date-time is equal to another date-time.
 <p>
 The comparison is based on the local date-time and the offset.
 To compare for the same instant on the time-line, use <a href="#isEqual(java.time.OffsetDateTime)"><code>isEqual(java.time.OffsetDateTime)</code></a>.
 Only objects of type <code>OffsetDateTime</code> are compared, other types return false.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Overrides:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/Object.html#equals(java.lang.Object)">equals</a></code>&nbsp;in class&nbsp;<code><a href="../lang/Object.html" title="class in java.lang">Object</a></code></dd>
<dt><span class="paramLabel">Parameters:</span></dt>
<dd><code>obj</code> - the object to check, null returns false</dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>true if this is equal to the other date-time</dd>
<dt><span class="seeLabel">See Also:</span></dt>
<dd><a href="../lang/Object.html#hashCode()"><code>Object.hashCode()</code></a>, 
<a href="../util/HashMap.html" title="class in java.util"><code>HashMap</code></a></dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="hashCode()">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockList">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>hashCode</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;int&nbsp;hashCode()</pre>
<div class="block">A hash code for this date-time.</div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Overrides:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/Object.html#hashCode()">hashCode</a></code>&nbsp;in class&nbsp;<code><a href="../lang/Object.html" title="class in java.lang">Object</a></code></dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>a suitable hash code</dd>
<dt><span class="seeLabel">See Also:</span></dt>
<dd><a href="../lang/Object.html#equals(java.lang.Object)"><code>Object.equals(java.lang.Object)</code></a>, 
<a href="../lang/System.html#identityHashCode(java.lang.Object)"><code>System.identityHashCode(java.lang.Object)</code></a></dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
<a id="toString()">
<!--   -->
</a>
<ul class="blockListLast">
<li class="blockList">
<h4>toString</h4>
<pre class="methodSignature">public&nbsp;<a href="../lang/String.html" title="class in java.lang">String</a>&nbsp;toString()</pre>
<div class="block">Outputs this date-time as a <code>String</code>, such as <code>2007-12-03T10:15:30+01:00</code>.
 <p>
 The output will be one of the following ISO-8601 formats:
 <ul>
 <li><code>uuuu-MM-dd'T'HH:mmXXXXX</code></li>
 <li><code>uuuu-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ssXXXXX</code></li>
 <li><code>uuuu-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSXXXXX</code></li>
 <li><code>uuuu-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSSSSXXXXX</code></li>
 <li><code>uuuu-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSSSSSSSXXXXX</code></li>
 </ul>
 The format used will be the shortest that outputs the full value of
 the time where the omitted parts are implied to be zero.</p></div>
<dl>
<dt><span class="overrideSpecifyLabel">Overrides:</span></dt>
<dd><code><a href="../lang/Object.html#toString()">toString</a></code>&nbsp;in class&nbsp;<code><a href="../lang/Object.html" title="class in java.lang">Object</a></code></dd>
<dt><span class="returnLabel">Returns:</span></dt>
<dd>a string representation of this date-time, not null</dd>
</dl>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</section>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</main>
